Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: The role of gene duplication and symbiont association in the evolution of sea anemone venom
Award.AbstractNarration:
The diversity of venoms within a group of organisms is largely the product of gene duplication and subsequent DNA sequence diversification. The specifics of this process remain obscure in most organisms. The planned research uses sea anemones (Cnidaria: Anthozoa, Actiniaria) as a model to understand the genome-level processes like gene duplications in shaping venom repertoire. The incidence of gene duplication and the processes by which duplicated genes diversify or become non-functional can be inferred through the analysis of the sequences that flank functional venom genes and the regions of the genome in which venoms are particularly common.

Sea anemones are part of the oldest and largest group of extant venomous animals. Their venoms exhibit a variety of functions, including disrupting the control of ion channels, destabilizing cellular membranes, or inhibiting synthesis of lipids. The functional and structural diversity of venoms is underpinned by an even greater degree of diversity at the genetic level. This more detailed account of venom diversity thus has potential for studies of function and structure of venom, and may have applications of interest to pharmacological or medical research. Additional benefits to the broader community include the training of graduate and undergraduate students, outreach to general and technical audiences through presentations, and published scientific studies of gene diversity and evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Venom is one of the most dynamic adaptations of animals. The mechanisms involved with venom evolution and diversification are complex, yet every major animal lineage contains examples of venomous animals. Through this project, we characterized the genomic diversity of venoms in one of the oldest lineages of animals, sea anemones. Similar to the venoms of snakes, cone snails, or other animals, sea anemone venom is a cocktail of neurotoxins, cytolytic toxins, and protein degraders. Although similar in having these basic parts, different lineages of sea anemone shave different specific components and have those components mixed in different proportions.

Recognizing the diversity in venom composition across lineages, we sought to understand the mechanisms and consequences of this genetic diversification.  Our primary goal was to identify regions in the genome that may have undergone wholesale duplication to produce novel copies of genes the encode venom proteins.  In cases where duplications occur, natural selection may preserve the function of the new copy of the gene, or one of the copies may be released from functional constraint and eventaually adopt new functions. For venom, the evolution of new function is usually associated with an expansion in the cellular targets of the venom.

Our study leveraged previous work on the model organism Nematostella vectensis. Genome sequencing of this sea anemone provided information that identified possible tandem repeats, areas of the genome where there are many sequential copies of highly similar genes. We sequenced partial genomes of four species of sea anemone (Haloclava producta, Epiactis japonicus, Heteractis crispa, and Stichodactyla haddoni) to identify additional tandem duplication events, but failed to identify the single conserved venom gene with eight tandem copies found in N. vectensis. In these new systems, we found more numerous and more diverse copies of venom genes but no tandem duplication. This difference may reflect the use of partial versus complete genomes, but also probably reflects the deep evolutionary distance between N. vectensis and the species we studied.

This work has significantly increased the overall representation and diversity of venom genes known for sea anemones and has placed this diversity in both ecological and evolutionary context. This is foundational to understanding how venom evolves across the many animal systems in which it occurs. We have also developed a bioinformatics pipeline to identify toxin genes from transcriptomic and genomic datasets and also surveyed genomes venomous outside of sea anemones for the occurrence of tandem duplication events. This work has involved the training of graduate students and mentoring of undergraduates, resulting in several peer-reviewed publications and public presentations.
